title: Mahatma Gandhi Marine National Park
short_description: A protected marine life sanctuary in the Andaman Islands, famous for its coral reefs and sea turtles.
long_description: Mahatma Gandhi Marine National Park is a national park of India near Wandoor on the Andaman Islands. It belongs to the South Andaman administrative district, part of the Indian union territory of Andaman and Nicobar Islands. The park was created on 24 May 1983 under the Wildlife Protection Act of 1972 to protect massive marine life such as corals and nesting sea turtles prevalent in the area. It comprises 15 islands of mangrove creeks, tropical rainforest and reefs supporting 50 types of coral.
wildlife_significance: Protects endangered coral reefs and nesting grounds for sea turtles.
major_experiences: Glass bottom boat ride to view corals
Visit Jolly Buoy Island (No plastic zone)
guides_and_tips: Only Jolly Buoy or Red Skin island is open at a time (alternating every 6 months). Strictly no plastic allowed.
how_to_reach: By Air: Port Blair (25 km). By Road: Local bus or taxi from Port Blair to Wandoor jetty.
permits_and_fees: Permit required from Forest Dept (Wandoor). Boat tickets separate.
conservation_notes: Coral bleaching is a threat. Global warming monitoring is active.
sample_itinerary: Day Trip: Drive from Port Blair to Wandoor (45 min). Take permit. Board boat to Jolly Buoy (45 min). Snorkeling/Glass bottom boat. Return to Wandoor by 2 PM. Sunset at Wandoor beach. Return.
safety_tips: Do not touch corals. Jellyfish warnings usually issued.

operating_season.season_notes: Jolly Buoy usually open Nov-May. Red Skin May-Oct.
